original_title: Impact of US tariff issue on India beginning to tell on local bourse
original_body_lines: The CSE kicked off in a positive manner at the outset yesterday but later indicated some sluggishness as investors were cautious over the impact on India of the US tariff issues. This is so because India is one of Sri Lanka’s main trading partners, stock market analysts said.

Both indices pointed to mixed reactions. The All Share Price Index went up by 24.5 points while S and P SL20 declined by 2.6 points. Turnover stood at Rs 3.26 billion with one crossing. The crossing was reported in Prime Lands, which crossed two million shares to the tune of Rs 39 million; its shares traded at Rs 19.50.

In the retail market top seven companies that mainly contributed to the turnover were; JKH Rs 179 million (7.6 million shares traded), Prime Lands Rs 135 million (6.9 million shares traded), Galle Face Capital Partners Rs 116 million (1.67 million shares traded), Hemas Holdings Rs 111 million (3.6 million shares traded), Lankem Developments Rs 102 million (four million shares traded), Ceylan Land Equity Rs 98 million (nine million shares traded) and Vallibel One Rs 91 million (962,000 shares traded). During the day 115 million share volumes changed hands in 29759 transactions. It is said that manufacturing sector counters, especially JKH, led the market followed by real estate companies, especially Prime Lands.
Yesterday, the rupee opened at Rs 300.75/85 to the US dollar in the spot market, flat from Rs 300.85/90 the previous day, while bond yields were steady, dealers said.

A bond maturing on 15.10.2028 was quoted at 8.80/90 percent. A bond maturing on 15.10.2029 was quoted at 9.35/37 percent. A bond maturing on 15.12.2029 was quoted at 9.38/41 percent from 9.39/40 percent. A bond maturing on 15.12.2032 was quoted at 10.25/33 percent, from 10.25/30 percent.
